--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Hey Derek, is the idea here that the X and Y
> coordinates
> would be "picked" or just looked at next?  In other
> words,
> is the net "looking around" at all the cards as it
> chooses?
> That would seem to be a way of doing this- have a
> limited 
> input field but allow it move it around and look at
> all the cards, and then make a decision (with a
> separate output
> node) when it wants to.

I was thinking it would be simpler to just have the X
and Y coordinate output be the next cards picked.  I'm
not sure in Concentration that there needs to be much
of a "looking around" phase before the net makes two
choices.  The only information it would get from
looking around (if you stuck to the rules of the game)
would be whether or not a particular space had a card
or was empty, right?  

I'd think you'd want the selection pressure to drive
the net to memorize this information, and I would tend
to think it would take much longer for the net to
evolve such memory if you allowed it to wander across
the tableau every turn before making its pick.

Either way, the fitness of an individual is simply
based on the number of turns (or if we allowed a
wandering phase, the number of looks at the tableau)
it takes to clear the tableau.  It would be
interesting to evolve nets that have a looking phase,
and an additional output to indicate their choice, and
compare the progress of runs against nets that just
pick two positions each turn, without looking around.

Eventually, you'd want their actual behavior to
converge, right?  That is, you'd want the looking
around phase to get shorter and shorter so that the
network could memorize the board and make more
efficient choices each turn.  It would be interesting
to see which approach yields a better player in less
time.

Hmm...so many interesting domains, so little time. :)

Derek
